item.title: Vim Easy TODO
item.description:
Today I released my very first Vim plugin called Vim Easy TODO. I’m using Vim for about 3 weeks now, and I like it a lot. I still have a lot to learn, but I’m looking forward to it. I needed some To-do list plugin like PlainTasks for Sublime Text. But I didn’t want to use some “heavy” plugin, I just needed to have some basic, formatted/colorized To-do list. So I decided to write it for myself. It’s not perfect, but it does the job. It has some basic customization feature, but not too much. Keep it simple and stupid, you now. :)

Vim Easy TODO is a simple & easy to use ‘To-do list’ plugin for - of course - Vim. For those who need only some basic functionality when creating To-do lists.

If you interested, please visit the project’s page on github:

https://github.com/spcmd/vim-easy-todo

item.title: ubsi
item.description:
ubsi is a simple Ubuntu System Information script, similar to Archey, but ubsi is simpler, it comes only with an Ubuntu logo ascii (so no other distro logos included). I made it for my system, you might have to tweak it here and there.

You can copy this script to somewhere in your $PATH (e.g. ~/bin), make it executable (chmod +x /path/to/ubsi) then you can run ubsi to get the system information. Or you can put this code into your .bashrc or to a separate file, it’s your choice how you use it.

item.title: qxbacklight
item.description:
A bash script for setting the brightness with xbacklight quickly.

Dependencies

  • xbacklight

Installation

  1. Clone the repository (https://github.com/spcmd/qxbacklight.git) or download from Github.
  2. Copy qxbacklight to somewhere in your $PATH (for example: ~/bin) or copy wherever you like, then give the full path to the script when using it.
  3. Make it executable (for example: chmod +x /path/to/qxbacklight)
  4. Open the script with a text editor and configure the options (see Configurable Options and the detailed comments in the script).
  5. Create keybinds for the qxbacklight commands (see Commands)

Commands

  • qxbacklight --help Help & basic information.
  • qxbacklight --up Increase brightness.
  • qxbacklight --down Decrease brightness.
  • qxbacklight --default Set brightness value to default.

Configurable Options

Strongly recommended to configure these options for yourself!
I left my values as a default (for reference: I’m using a Notebook with LED LCD display, which is very bright, so my values are relatively low).

  • DEFAULT_BR=18 Default brightness (in percentage).
  • STEP_AMOUNT=2 Decrease/increase brightness steps (in percentage).
  • NOTIFY="yes" Send notification when setting the brightness.

Notes:

  • Use xbacklight -get command to get the current brightness value, so you can set it at DEFAULT_BR as a default.
  • Since xbacklight -get returns a floating point number (e.g. 17.989757) you should round this value to make an integer (e.g. 18), and use this number as a default (DEFAULT_BR)
  • STEP_AMOUNT will be added (increase/brigtness up) or substracted (decrease/brigtness down) from the current brightness value.
  • The NOTIFY option works as a feedback (with notify-send command): it shows the new brightness value after setting the brightness. If you don’t want a notification, just leave it empty (NOTIFY="").

Example keybinds for Openbox

If you are using Openbox as a Window Manager, you can copy&paste these keybinds below into the Openbox key configuration file (~/.config/openbox/rc.xml), then reconfigure or restart Openbox (openbox --reconfigure or openbox --restart).

<keybind key="C-W-Left">
    <action name="Execute">
        <command>qxbacklight --down</command>
    </action>
</keybind>
<keybind key="C-W-Right">
    <action name="Execute">
        <command>qxbacklight --up</command>
    </action>
</keybind>
<keybind key="C-W-KP_0">
    <action name="Execute">
        <command>qxbacklight --default</command>
    </action>
</keybind>

Notes:

  • Make sure you configure the keybind keys for yourself.
  • If you didn’t copy qxbacklight to somewhere in your $PATH (see Installation), then you need to edit the <command> lines by setting the correct path to the script (for example: <command>/path/to/qxbacklight --up</command>)

item.title: Port.hu EPG userstyle
item.description:
Összehasonlítás (Előtte - Utána)

Userstyle

Használhatod a Stylish kiegészítővel (vagy más userstyle kezelő kiegészítővel), vagy a teheted a Firefox userContent.css fájljába is.

A userstyle a http://port.hu/tv/pls/tv/oldtv.prog címmel működik, ami a régebbi víszszintes elrendezésű felület. Lehetséges, hogy ez már csak regisztrált felhasználóként érhető el.

item.title: Firefox > mpv
item.description:
Simple bash script for opening youtube videos and other videos in mpv from Firefox & log watched videos (into a local html file), if you want. Currently the logging option works only with Youtube and Vimeo videos.

Update (2015.04.20.): added auto stop/play Spotify options.

You can find the documentation and the instructions on the Github page:

https://github.com/spcmd/firefox-mpv

item.title: Obsnapper
item.description:
I made this bash script for window snapping function under Openbox. I made this for practicing bash and for my personal use. I don’t plan on taking feature requests or whatever. However, It works for me, so I decided to share this as a project.

I’m using this script under Ubuntu 14.04 with Openbox 3.5.2 and tint2 0.11+svn20121014 at resolution 1366x768 and 1280x800.

Features

  • Window snapping to left and right
  • Restoring window position or restoring window to a fixed position

Dependencies

  • xwininfo
  • xprop
  • wmctrl
  • using a panel or dock with openbox

Configurable options

  • PANEL_NAME="" (string ; name of the panel or dock ; for example: tint2)
  • PANEL_ID="" (string ; only if PANEL_NAME is not working ; for example: 0x40006b)
  • PANEL_TYPE="" (string ; options: left, top, bottom)
  • PX_CORR_LPT= (integer ; some pixel correction, mainly beacause of borders ; you can use this when PANEL_TYPE is set to “left” ; for example: 2)
  • RESTORE_BEHAVIOUR="" (string ; options: dynamic, fixed)

  • TOP_MARGIN= (integer ; margin from the top (in pixel), when RESTORE_BEHAVIOUR is set to “fixed” ; for example: 10)

  • Notes:
    • Do not use quotation marks ("") with integer type options!
    • Run xwininfo in terminal, then click on the panel/dock to get the PANEL_NAME and other window informations.

Installation

  1. Clone this script (git clone https://github.com/spcmd/Obsnapper.git) or download from Github and copy it to somewhere in your $PATH (for example: ~/bin or /usr/bin) or copy wherever you like, then give the full path to the script when using it.
  2. Make it executable (for example: chmod +x /path/to/obsnapper)
  3. Open the script with a text editor and configure the options (see Configurable options and the detailed comments in the script).
  4. Create keybinds for the snapping functions in the Openbox key configuration file (~/.config/openbox/rc.xml), then restart Openbox (openbox --restart).

Example keybinds

For snapping to left with Super+Left and to right with Super+Right, you can copy&paste these keybinds below into ~/.config/openbox/rc.xml if you copied the Obsnapper script somewhere in your $PATH. To restore active window, simply hit one of these key combinations again.

If the Obsnapper script wasn’t copied to somewhere in your $PATH, you need to change the <command> lines to use the full path (for example <command>/path/to/obsnapper --snapleft</command>)

<!-- Window snap Left -->
    <keybind key="W-Left">
      <action name="If">
        <maximizedvertical>yes</maximizedvertical>
        <maximizedhorizontal>no</maximizedhorizontal>
        <then>
          <action name="Execute">
            <command>obsnapper --restore</command>
          </action>
        </then>
        <else>
          <action name="If">
            <maximizedvertical>no</maximizedvertical>
            <maximizedhorizontal>no</maximizedhorizontal>
            <then>
              <action name="Execute">
                <command>obsnapper --snapleft</command>
              </action>
            </then>
          </action>
        </else>
      </action>
    </keybind>
    <!-- Window snap Right -->
    <keybind key="W-Right">
      <action name="If">
        <maximizedvertical>yes</maximizedvertical>
        <maximizedhorizontal>no</maximizedhorizontal>
        <then>
          <action name="Execute">
            <command>obsnapper --restore</command>
          </action>
        </then>
        <else>
          <action name="If">
            <maximizedvertical>no</maximizedvertical>
            <maximizedhorizontal>no</maximizedhorizontal>
            <then>
              <action name="Execute">
                <command>obsnapper --snapright</command>
              </action>
            </then>
          </action>
        </else>
      </action>
    </keybind>

Command line options

  • obsnapper --help List available options.
  • obsnapper --check Check for configuration errors.
  • obsnapper --snapleft Snap window to left
  • obsnapper --snapright Snap window to right
  • obsnapper --restore Restore window position

  • obsnapper --version , obsnapper -v Version information

  • Notes:
    • You can use one command at a time, but you can chain commands with && if you like (for example: obsnapper --snapleft && obsnapper --restore)
    • A --restore should always follow a snap to get the script work properly.

item.title: Hello World!
item.description:
Nothing special here, just a starter post for my new site.

#include<stdio.h>

main()
{
    printf("Hello World!");
}
